Award.AwardTitle: NSF Student Travel Grant for 2020 IEEE International Conference on Pervasive Computing and Communications (PerCom)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: This award is to assist US-based students to attend the 2020 IEEE International Conference on Pervasive Computing and Communications (PerCom) to be held in Austin, Texas, March 23-27, 2020. Participation in PerCom 2020 and similar conferences are valuable and important activities of the graduate school experience. It provides students with the opportunity to interact with more senior researchers, and exposes students to leading work and practical industry practices in this important area of research. This may have an important impact on career development.<br/><br/>The conference spans five days and will consist of technical paper presentations, panels, industry presentations, posters, and demonstrations. It will also feature keynote speeches from leading researchers and practitioners in the field. <br/><br/>Student travel to conferences is an important activity. Funds will be dispersed with preference given to students who would not otherwise be able to attend the conference and paying particular attention to diversity and relevance of the student's research interest.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The IEEE International Conference on Pervasive Computing and Communications (PerCom) is a flagship conference in the area of pervasive computing and networking dealing with internet of things, cyber-physical systems, and smart systems (e.g., smart city, smart energy, smart healthcare, etc.). The NSF travel funds helped support 9 U.S. based students to attend IEEE PerCom in 2020 conference held virtually on March 23-27, 2020 and 23 U.S. based students attend IEEE PerCom 2021 conference held virtually on March 22-26, 2021 respectively (www.percom.org). More than a dozen of these students were women and six were under-represented minority students. They consisted of a mix of B.S., M.S. and Ph.D. students from smaller schools to big name schools.

 

Intellectual Merit: Papers presented at the IEEE PerCom 2020 and PerCom 2021 conferences were very high quality. The technical programs included a wide variety of topics in pervasive computing and networking and emerging topics like smartphone sensing, mobile crowdsensing, smart city, security and social networks with applications to cyber-physical-human systems, smart and connected communities, smart healthcare, internet of things (IoT), security, energy and sustainability. The conference offered a valuable opportunity for the supported U.S. based students to attend keynote talks and technical sessions, learn about state-of-the-art research in pervasive computing, systems and applications through paper presentations and panel discussions, and participate in the Ph.D. forum, workshops, demo, poster, and work-in-progress sessions. The students also got the opportunity to network with peers and top notch researchers in pervasive computing. They were highly motivated to pursue high quality research and eventually research careers upon graduation.

 

Broader Impacts. The NSF travel grant supported 18 students including women and under-represented minority students, to attend a flagship conference IEEE PerCom 2020 and PerCom 2021. The NSF travel grant opportunity was widely advertised that led to the selection of students competitively from an application pool of more than 60 students. Without NSF travel support, many of these students would not have otherwise attended this flagship conference.
